column2: INTRODUCTION TO OPERATING SYSTEMS AND NETWORKING TECHNOLOGY
column6: Lab-oriented survey of desktop/network OS essentials, including file/disk management, system tools utilization, resource sharing and introductory network concepts.
Builds expertise in creating business documents applying the basic features of popular word processing software. Emphasis on hands on experience. Lecture 2 hours. Lab 2 hours.
Design and create documents by using advanced features of word processing software. Lecture 2 hours, lab 2 hours.

Development and production of professional computer-projected presentation materials using popular software. Includes use of graphic design techniques, color layout design principles and transparencies. Lecture 1 hour. Lab 2 hours.
Introduction to the role of data and its management and evolution to information and knowledge in business environments.
Concepts, terminology and use of current database software to manage and retrieve business information. Emphasis on hands-on experiences. Lecture 2 hour. Lab 2 hour.
Overview database course designed for medical billing certificate majors as they add, query, and create forms and generate reports for medical environments.

column2: SYSTEMS STUDIES FOR MEDICAL BILLING AND CODING
column6: Overview course to link knowledge of body systems with coding procedures in medical facilities. Corequisite: ITAP 26651 or HED 14020.

Basic keyboarding course using computers for students having no previous keyboarding instruction or a speed of less than 30 words a minute. To pass the course students must keyboard above 30 words a minute for three minutes with no more than three errors.
Use of electronic spreadsheets from beginning to advanced applications that may prepare for software certification. Lecture 2 hours. Lab 2 hours.
Basic transcription of machine dictation, application of language skills to typical and specialized office documents; and mastery of proofreading/editing procedures and techniques.

Study and application of the principles of proper document design using high-end desktop publishing software for newsletters, brochures, reports, forms and other computer-based business documents. Lecture 2 hours, lab 2 hours.

High-end layout/design and illustration software. Includes advanced documents, Web publishing, makeovers, computer graphic concepts and formatting, image editing techniques and the use of color. Lecture 1 hour, lab 4 hours.
Explores how office professionals can apply resource management skills to the areas of space/workflow, forms, budgetary control, staff and materials supplies.

Provides the basic tools needed to effectively manage projects and to automate and streamline such functions as resource allocation, work scheduling and communication. Project management software is used in the course. Lecture .5 hours lab,1 hour.

Transcription of machine dictation emphasizing documents relating to the legal or medical professions. Includes application of language skills and mastery of proofreading/editing procedures and techniques.

Theory and application of oral and written business communication with emphasis on business letters, reports, employment process, visual presentations and electronic communications. Basic word processing skills are suggested.

Introductory course in the preparation of various medical documents and forms in the health care industry. Use of computers and various word processing software will be included. Lecture 2 hours, lab 2 hours.
Analysis of the language and terms used in medical billing environments. The medical billing context is used to frame the study of prefixes, suffixes and root words by specialty.
Basic medical coding using the current version of the ICD classification system and nomenclature.
Introduction to coding rules for the CPT and Level II coding systems, incorporating and applying ICD rules to code patient services.

Refines job search strategies, integrates coursework with realistic office settings, presents interpersonal/ethical issues and provides outreach activities, emphasizing the total quality management environment.

column4: Sophomore standing and 2.00 GPA or better in major and special approval.
column6: Supervised field experience of ten hours per week paid or seven hours per week unpaid in a business environment functioning as an administrative professional. Repeatable for a total of 4 hours.

column2: SPECIAL TOPICS IN INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FOR ADMINISTRATIVE PROFESSIONALS
column6: Special topics in information technology topics for administrative professionals. Repeated registration permitted.

column2: INDIVIDUAL INVESTIGATION:INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY FOR ADMINISTRATIVE PROFESSIONALS
column4: 12 credit hours of ITAP courses and special approval of a full-time ITAP faculty member.
column6: Independent, in-depth research of an ITAP topic supervised and coordinated by an ITAP faculty member.
